column1: # NOTICE: This file was automatically generated by https://github.com/khimaros/enc using the following invocation: enc question.en -o answer.csv
# provide a detailed mathematical formula to describe all of physics

column5: Description

The total action combines General Relativity (via the Einstein-Hilbert action) and the Standard Model. The principle of least action states that the path taken by the system corresponds to an extremum of this action. This currently represents the most complete fundamental description of the universe, excluding phenomena like dark matter and dark energy.
The action for the gravitational field as described by General Relativity.
The curvature of spacetime, a measure of how the volume of a small ball in curved space deviates from that of a standard ball in Euclidean space.
A tensor representing the amount by which the volume of a geodesic ball in a curved Riemannian manifold deviates from that of the standard ball in Euclidean space.
A tensor that defines the geometry of spacetime, used to measure distances, angles, and volumes.
The determinant of the metric tensor, used in the volume element for integration over spacetime.
A fundamental physical constant quantifying the magnitude of the gravitational force between two bodies.
A fundamental physical constant, the speed at which all massless particles and associated fields travel in a vacuum.
The Lagrangian density for the Standard Model, describing the dynamics of all known elementary particles and their interactions via the electromagnetic, weak, and strong forces.
Describes the kinetics and self-interactions of the force-carrying gauge bosons (gluons, W/Z bosons, photons).
column6: -1/4 G^a_μν G_a^μν - 1/4 W^a_μν W_a^μν - 1/4 B_μν B^μν

column5: Describes the field of the strong force carriers (gluons).
column6: ∂_μ G^a_ν - ∂_ν G^a_μ + g_s f^abc G^b_μ G^c_ν

column5: Describes the field of the weak force carriers (W bosons).
column6: ∂_μ W^a_ν - ∂_ν W^a_μ + g f^abc W^b_μ W^c_ν

column5: Describes the field of the weak hypercharge (related to photons and Z bosons).
Describes the kinetic energy of matter particles (quarks and leptons) and their interactions with the gauge bosons.
A quantum field representing a specific type of fermion (e.g., electron, up quark).
An operator that incorporates the effects of gauge fields, ensuring the Lagrangian is gauge invariant.
column6: D_μ = ∂_μ - i g_s (λ^a/2)G^a_μ - i g (τ^a/2)W^a_μ - i g' (Y/2)B_μ

column5: Matrices in the Dirac equation that describe the properties of spin-1/2 particles.
Describes the kinetic energy, self-interaction, and potential of the Higgs field, which gives mass to W and Z bosons via spontaneous symmetry breaking.
A scalar field that permeates all of space; its non-zero vacuum expectation value breaks the electroweak symmetry.
The potential energy of the Higgs field, which has a 'mexican hat' shape, leading to a non-zero vacuum expectation value.
Describes the interaction between the Higgs field and fermion fields, which gives mass to the fermions (quarks and leptons).
column6: -Σ_f y_f (L̄_f Φ R_f + R̄_f Φ† L_f)

column5: A constant for each fermion type that determines the strength of its interaction with the Higgs field, and thus its mass.
Chiral components of the fermion spinor fields, which interact differently with the weak force.
